guide.introduction: While Final Cut Express and Final Cut Pro are excellent tools for editing video, the current versions don't natively support video formats that DSLRs and other video cameras record in. This guide will show you how to convert footage from a Canon 5D Mark II for use with Final Cut Pro. You can use this method for many types of cameras and video formats.
guide.introduction_rendered:
While Final Cut Express and Final Cut Pro are excellent tools for editing video, the current versions don't natively support video formats that DSLRs and other video cameras record in. This guide will show you how to convert footage from a Canon 5D Mark II for use with Final Cut Pro. You can use this method for many types of cameras and video formats.

Tools
  • Final Cut Pro
  • MPEG Streamclip

lines.text: Either copy the video files from your camera to your computer's hard drive or work directly off the memory card:
lines.text_raw: Either copy the video files from your camera to your computer's hard drive or work directly off the memory card:

lines.text: To copy the files from your camera: plug your camera into your computer via USB and use Apple's Image Capture application to copy the files from the camera to a temporary folder on your computer.
lines.text_raw: '''To copy the files from your camera:''' plug your camera into your computer via USB and use Apple's Image Capture application to copy the files from the camera to a temporary folder on your computer.

lines.text: To work directly off the memory card: remove the memory card from the camera and insert it into a card reader connected to your computer.
lines.text_raw: '''To work directly off the memory card:''' remove the memory card from the camera and insert it into a card reader connected to your computer.

lines.text: You may want to save the original source files from the camera until your project is totally complete.
lines.text_raw: You may want to save the original source files from the camera until your project is totally complete.

steps.title: Add Files to MPEG Streamclip's Batch List

lines.text: Open MPEG Streamclip. It's a free download available from Squared 5
lines.text_raw: Open MPEG Streamclip. It's a free download available from [http://www.squared5.com/|Squared 5]

lines.text: From the "List" menu choose "Batch List" or type Command+B.
lines.text_raw: From the "List" menu choose "Batch List" or type Command+B.

lines.text: Click the "Add Files..." button and navigate where your video files are located.
lines.text_raw: Click the "Add Files..." button and navigate where your video files are located.

lines.text: Select all the files you want to convert and click "To Batch"
lines.text_raw: Select all the files you want to convert and click "To Batch"

lines.text: You can also drag the files from Finder into the batch list window.
lines.text_raw: You can also drag the files from Finder into the batch list window.

lines.text: A window will appear asking you yo choose a task. Choose "Export to QuickTime" and leave the rest of the checkboxes unchecked.  Click OK.
lines.text_raw: A window will appear asking you yo choose a task. Choose "Export to QuickTime" and leave the rest of the checkboxes unchecked.  Click OK.

lines.text: Select a destination folder for your converted footage.
lines.text_raw: Select a destination folder for your converted footage.

lines.text: In the Compression drop down menu at the top, choose "Apple Intermediate Codec"
lines.text_raw: In the Compression drop down menu at the top, choose "Apple Intermediate Codec"

lines.text: Drag the quality slider to 90% (or whatever your preference)
lines.text_raw: Drag the quality slider to 90% (or whatever your preference)

lines.text: Under Frame Size, choose the option that leaves your video unscaled.
lines.text_raw: Under Frame Size, choose the option that leaves your video unscaled.

lines.text: Leave the other settings as is.
lines.text_raw: Leave the other settings as is.
